5. Discussion 506 

Structures and sedimentation in northwestern Mozambique followed important 507 

stages of intraplate brittle reactivation of large crustal structures within Gondwana 508 

Supercontinent, as marked by the overlap of very coarse lithofacies association of Matinde 509 

Formation over the floodplains of Moatize Formation, which is cross-cut by several 510 

transtensive syn-depositional structures. NW-oriented structures such as growth faults, drag 511 

folds and folds axial planes, produced by regional tectonic activity, have exposed buried 512 

coal beds in the northeast area of Cahora Bassa Basin, which is positioned north-northwest 513 

of the Moatize-Minjova Basin (Fig. 2C), with the same sedimentation pattern of the latter. 514 

The entire sequence shows a distinct regional coarsening upwards signature, which 515 

compounds a large fluvial plane during Permian in the northwestern Mozambique basins.  516 

Brittle faults and fractures measurements collected from the Moatize and Matinde 517 

formations point to preponderant post-Karoo depositional tectonic reactivations, probably 518 

related to the Pangea breakup event and beginning of the East African Rift System 519 

inception. Below we provide a discussion about integration of structural reactivation 520 

mechanisms and depositional environments.  521 

 522 

5.1. Permian Tectonics and Basin Subsidence  523 

A complex structural web was identified in northwestern Mozambique, produced by 524 

Phanerozoic brittle reactivation of inherited basement Precambrian ductile deformation 525 

zones, mostly from Pan-African orogenic cycle. NW-SE oriented structures tightly 526 

dominate the Moatize-Minjova Basin during deposition and subsidence phases of Karoo 527 

Supergroup sequences in northwestern Mozambique. The large distribution of the 528 



32 

 

lineament patterns all over the region reflects the Mozambican position within the Pan-529 

African assembly, between the interface of the Zambezi and Mozambique Orogenies. 530 

The NW-SE pattern is concordant with the southeastern segment of the Mzarabani 531 

Shear Zone and Mwanza and Estima Faults (Fig. 2) which are the main fault systems 532 

responsible for basin subsidence. The WNW-ESE subgroup is probably a subordinate 533 

(Riedell shear) pattern generated from the NW-SE system. On the other hand, the E-W 534 

transtension system represents the southern and northern boundary of the greater Cahora 535 

Bassa Basin, while the ENE-WSW and NNE-SSW fault systems represent the Riedell 536 

shear. Shoko and Gwavava (1999) identify similar structures in the basement below Cahora 537 

Bassa Basin from geophysical data and assigned those as the main structural pattern 538 

responsible to control subsidence control within the basin, since its earliest stages. 539 

However, NE-trending fault zones show greater importance in the Moatize-Minjova Basin, 540 

near the northeastern edge of Mozambique with Malawi, where several Jurassic dikes are 541 

aligned with this trend (Casting, 1991).  Our studies from granitic and metamorphic rocks 542 

in Cahora Bassa and Tete regions showed that basement ductile structures are marked by 543 

NW-SE oriented magmatic fabric and high temperature shear zones (Philipp et al., 2014). 544 

Additionally, NW-SE and NE-SW are the main Pan-African ductile shear-zones patterns, 545 

well established in northern Malawi (Ring et al., 2002), active until Ordovician times. 546 

These considerations imply that the basement fabric heritage within northern Mozambique 547 

has played an important role during basin inception and infilling.  548 

Apparently, NW-SE, WNW-ESE, and ENE-WSW fault system subgroups appear to 549 

affect more intensively the KS sequences and the Post-Karoo sequences less (Fig. 5), 550 

comprising some of the longest continuous lineaments observed as indicative of its basin-551 

forming character. Igneous rocks from Karoo are strongly aligned and sectioned by the 552 



33 

 

NW-SE subgroup. We interpreted these data as probable pathways for magmatic rise 553 

through the crust at the end of the Karoo basinal cycle (beginning of Gondwana Breakup), 554 

controlling regional subsidence during Karoo and Post-Karoo sedimentation. Similar 555 

descriptions could be adopted for the WNW-ESE, and ENE-WSW subgroups, which are 556 

also well recorded in the Karoo sequences; but these two subgroups host only small 557 

intrusions and are probably shallower in the crust. 558 

The less pronounced N-S and NNE-SSW fault system scarcely affect the basins, 559 

comprising smaller lengths, and hence are probably shallower fault zones resembling 560 

subsidiary structures associated with the greater patterns. Otherwise, they intercept the 561 

Later Karoo volcanic intrusions in the southern region, constraining its post-Karoo tectonic 562 

age.  563 

A dynamic analysis based on field scale data suggests a local NNE-SSW 564 

extensional regime to generate such structural pattern (Fig. 12). Since they post-date Karoo 565 

sedimentation, due to its large occurrence all over the basin and great fit with the N-S 566 

trending East African Rift structure (Lake Niassa), this extensional component is probably 567 

related to an N-S transtensional regime produced during the Gondwana dispersal in the 568 

eastern African margin.    569

35 

 

In a regional context, Permian times were a period of large tectonic activity along 578 

Gondwana, such as the Pangea assembly (Variscan Orogeny) in northern Africa (Torsvik & 579 

Cocks, 2013; Linol et al., 2015) and ongoing subduction of Panthalassan oceanic crust 580 

(Gondwanides Orogeny, ca. 305–230 Ma) in the southwestern Gondwana/Pangea margin 581 

(Cawood & Buchan, 2007). Both tectonic processes may have acted as a trigger for 582 

regional inland subsidence that took place in several basins within Gondwana. This period 583 

accomplished the Cape Fold Belt Orogeny, which comprises a large deformation structural 584 

pattern with major N-S (Craddock et al., 2007) to NE-SW stress fields acting on the 585 

Gondwana margin (Tankard et al., 2009; Hansma et al., 2015), which deformed earlier 586 

glaciogenic deposits of KS in South Africa (Craddock et al., 2007; Hansma et al., 2015). 587 

Additionally, Smith et al. (1993), Cadle et al. (1993), Johnson et al. (1996). Catuneanu et 588 

al. (2005) and references therein indicate that glaciogenic deposits commonly rest non-589 

conformably or with a slightly angular unconformity over low relief pre-Karoo landscape. 590 

These evidences suggests that it starts after the main glacial period, probably during Early 591 

Permian as constrained by Ar-Ar deformational ages of ca. 280-245 Ma within the Cape 592 

Fold Belt (Hansma et al., 2015), prior to the onset of coal-bearing layers deposition of 593 

Moatize Formation, which recorded large syn-depositional faulting and folding in its 594 

stratigraphic record (Vasconcelos et al., 2014; Lakshminarayana, 2015). Basin inversion 595 

and basement uplift during this period have also been documented by Holz et al. (2006) in 596 

the southern section of the Paraná Basin in South America, improving the influence of 597 

southern Gondwana margin tectonics inland.  598 

In this context, we understand that the Moatize-Minjova Basin was developed by a 599 

NW-trending structural system, with sinistral transtensive regime, related to N-S/NE-SW 600 

oriented stress field from the Gondwana southern margin during the early times of the Cape 601 



36 

 

Orogeny evolution. Stress propagated along the first order, NE to NNE oriented, 602 

Precambrian Mozambique Ocean Suture and converged inland through the NW Zambezi 603 

Pre-Transform System as a synthetic Riedell shear of the main structure (Fig. 13A). 604 

Subsidence was achieved from a NE-SW extension, produced by crustal readjustment. On 605 

the other hand, episodic subsidence in Mid-Zambezi, Mana Pools, Luangwa, Metangula, 606 

Ruhuhu and Waterberg basins, that are NE-SW-trending, are related to readjustments 607 

produced by the Damara-Katanga Belt, between Kalahari and Congo/Tanzania cratonic 608 

areas (Fig. 13A).   609

5.2 Stratigraphic and Depositional Implications 615 

Fluvial channels or poorly confined channels, bars and overbanks are the main 616 

depositional elements identified in the area, composed by facies and facies associations 617 

characterizing individual bodies where the internal geometry and external form can be 618 

differentiated. These elements led us to identify meandering (Moatize Formation) and 619 

braided (Matinde Formation) fluvial systems.  620 

The facies description and facies associations of well CS_006A have shown that the 621 

Moatize Formation was deposited in a continental environment dominated by meandering 622 

river systems. Coals may have being deposited in peat associated with floodplains and 623 

probably in oxbow lakes (abandoned meandering channel; Fig. 13B). Thus, lateral 624 

migration of fluvial channels may have played an important hole in the matter of coal 625 

seams preservation. The study of the vertical lithofacies succession showed that coal is 626 

interbedded with thin layers of siltstone and fine sandstones, marking its cyclic deposition 627 

pattern. This sedimentary change within coal-bearing layers controls the quality of coal and 628 

is directly related to the deposition of crevasse splay successions.      629 

The stratigraphic sections demonstrated that the Chipanga seam, composed by 630 

interbedded flood fines and coal beds, occur near the base of the sequence (Fig. 7) and 631 

brings important subsidence implications with it. The great thickness of these floodplain 632 

fines deposits implies a high subsidence regime in the basin, with low fluvial channel 633 

amalgamation. This suggests an Early Permian depositional age, right after glacial retreat 634 

and consequent isostatic rebound which lead to high subsidence rates. This was followed by 635 

tectonically active periods throughout the Permian (as demonstrated earlier), due to the 636 

ongoing Panthalassa subduction along southern the Gondwana margin and the beginning of 637 

Cape Fold Belt deformation. Early Permian tectonic activity is recorded in basins on the 638 



39 

 

eastern margin, such as Ruhuhu Basin, near the Tanzanian margin (Fig. 1B), an important 639 

tectonic event around Artinskian times (Middle - Early Permian), which led to braided 640 

stream deposition in the base of the Moatize correlatable sequence (Wopfner, 2002). 641 

Therefore, the entire sequence is interpreted as a great fluvial plain, with large floodplain 642 

succession with thick peat seams accumulation in cold and wet swamps in the overbank 643 

areas. 644 

The stratigraphic analysis allowed the identification of a likely six-order sequence 645 

boundary on the uppermost portion of stratigraphic well CS_006A (depth of 28 m). It 646 

comprises an irregular surface marking the contact between the Moatize (Fig. 13B) and 647 

Matinde (Fig. 13C) formations, where load casts indicate an overlap of a coarse braided 648 

fluvial system over a meandering floodplain. However, these marks suggest that the hiatus 649 

between these two formations must not be great. This results in a very low probability of 650 

large peatland development with deposition of organic matter and coal formation in this 651 

range. Field analysis indicates a multiple-story channel fill and sandstone sheet complexes. 652 

Vasconcelos (2000) also pointed out that in some areas of northern Mozambique these two 653 

formations show some contemporarily as indicated by load casts in the contact between 654 

them. The overlap of coarse sandy to conglomeratic braided fluvial deposits implies in a 655 

change of the local geomorphology, associated with rift shoulders uplift during the Moatize 656 

Formation deposition, attributed to the earlier Gondwanides tectonic activity. The 657 

Gondwanides Orogeny was also responsible for coal seams deformation in its later stages. 658 

This tectonic activity led to distinct sedimentation patterns on different Karoo basins within 659 

Southern Africa and in South America basins. Changes in depositional style, as supported 660 

by lithofacies association through these basins, indicates plate readjustments and 661 

rejuvenation of local structural patterns.  662 



40 

 

The basin depocenter was probably located towards the southwestern limit of the 663 

basin, based on structural and coarsening upward sedimentary patterns and controlled by 664 

the Mzarabani Fault Zone, preserving a thick and more complete section of Matinde 665 

Formation. A southwestern depocenter position is also corroborated by geophysical data for 666 

the Cahora Bassa region presented by Orpen et al. (1989) and Shoko & Gwavava (1999), 667 

showing that the Mzarabani Shear Zone probably controlled basin subsidence 668 

southeastwards. These arguments are in agreement with GTK Consortium (2006) mapping, 669 

which show that these lithofacies transitioned to the Cádzi Formation (Fig. 3).  670 

The upper conglomeratic sequences can be interpreted in two ways. Basal matrix 671 

supported (Gm) conglomerates can represent alluvial fans deposits from the faulted margin. 672 

Finning upwards pattern, clasts organization and internal structures indicate main fluvial 673 

depositional control with northwards paleoflow. These elements may represent a coarser 674 

lithofacies association from the braided fluvial system (migration of longitudinal and/or 675 

accretion macroforms) or they can mark the transition to the upper Cadzi Formation, which 676 

may have occurred near Middle Triassic times, since the Matinde Formation is probably 677 

younger than Late Permian as determined by Pereira et al. (2016) (Fig. 14).  678 

This latter model counterpoints the GTK Consortium (2006) which interpreted these 679 

lithofacies as part of the Matinde Formation, which is the one we follow in this paper, due 680 

to the large distribution of geological mapping of these authors and to lateral stratigraphic 681 

relationships and depositional environments determined by us. Another strong aspect is the 682 

important tectonic period that commonly marks the Permian-Triassic transition in the 683 

Paraná Basin and other basins in South America and Africa (Zerfass et al., 2003; Zerfass et 684 

al., 2004; Zerfass et al., 2005; Catuneanu et al., 2005) and left an hiatus that can be 685 



41 

 

observed throughout the Tanzanian Karoo basins and in Mozambique (Catuneanu et al., 686 

2005).  687

The transition between the Moatize and Matinde formations probably approximates 691 

the Late Permian - Early Triassic period, based on palynological date presented earlier 692 

(Daber, 1984; Pereira et al., 2016) and other coal bearing seams deposits elsewhere in the 693 

Karoo basins (Catuneanu et al., 2005), although not all show clear tectonic implications. 694 

The Mid-Zambezi basin coal-bearing beds, correlatable to facies of the Moatize Formation, 695 

change to mostly mudstones with subordinate siltstones and sandstones of a lacustrine 696 

deposit (Nyambe & Utting, 1997). This suggests that high subsidence rates took place 697 

westwards from northern Mozambique, controlled by NE-SW crustal faults (Fig 13A), but 698 

produced for the same regional tectonic regime. This also improves the model proposed by 699 

Key et al. (2015) were a proto-Zambezi river with a western paleoflow since Early Permian 700 

times has influenced deposition in Central-Eastern Africa with thick proximal coarser 701 

lithofacies near the Precambrian orogenic belt and finer distal lithofacies inland towards the 702 

Mid-Zambezi and Kalahari Basins.  703 

 704 

6. Conclusions 705 

In summary, northwestern Mozambique basins were affected by NE-SW and NW-706 

SE transtensive trends, along the African eastern cratonic margin, which led to crustal 707 

readjustments of Precambrian structures and inland subsidence. Tectonic reactivation was 708 

produced by far-field stress transferred from the Gondwanides Orogeny and recorded in the 709 

sedimentary records of the Karoo basins in Mozambique and Southern Africa and also in 710 

South America basins. Identification of the same structural pattern of the basement units in 711 

the Karoo Supergroup and the latest coverage underscores the importance of tectonic 712 

reactivation of the same weakness zones in the depositional control of Paleozoic and 713 

Cenozoic units. 714 



43 

 

Permian sequences in the Moatize-Minjova Basin comprise mainly meandering and 715 

braided fluvial plane deposits. The former comprise floodplain, crevasse splay and fluvial 716 

channel main lithofacies associations. This sequence was prograded by a multiple-story 717 

braided fluvial plane in the Matinde Formation. Lithofacies associations and their 718 

relationship with each other suggest deposition within a fluvial confined to poorly confined 719 

channel system with longitudinal and low-angle lateral accretion macroforms. The top of 720 

the stratigraphic sequence comprises sediment gravity flow, channel and downstream 721 

macroform accretion facies associations. Conglomerates with boulders dominate near the 722 

southwestern fault bounded graben boundary, indicating an increase in the fluvial transport 723 

energy towards the top of the sequence, due to high relief geomorphologic depositional 724 

environment, which may have started during the end of the Moatize Formation depositional 725 

cycle. Northwestward paleoflow from Matinde lithofacies suggest that the Zambezi River 726 

flow was inverted during Permian sedimentation in northern Mozambique, with its 727 

headwaters located in the southeastern highland areas, inherited from the Pan-African 728 

orogeny.  729 

For further studies, we recommend conducting a stratigraphic detail study in the 730 

area to better understand the factors that controlled the deposition of the studied sediments. 731 

A more detailed stratigraphic model to describe the Triassic deposits in the region and 732 

Vúzi, Moatize and Matinde Formations elsewhere in northwestern Mozambique would 733 

improve tectonic and stratigraphic understanding in the area. 734

Abstract 26 

Permian-Triassic times were a period of high sedimentation rates into the 27 

intracontinental Karoo rift basin of northwestern Mozambique reflecting high 28 

exhumation rates in the underlying high grounded Precambrian-Cambrian basement 29 

assemblages. The U-Pb dating of detrital zircons from Permian-Triassic Matinde 30 

Formation of Karoo Supergroup proved to be a reliable proxy to map denudation 31 

patterns of source regions.  32 

 33 

The analytical data allow discriminate two main age populations of Late 34 

Mesoproterozoic - Early Neoproterozoic (ca. 1100-950 Ma) and a Late Neoproterozoic 35 

- Early Cambrian (ca. 550-490 Ma). The former resembles to the late stages of Rodinia 36 

Supercontinent geotectonic activity mostly represented by magmatic and less 37 

metamorphic rocks, which are present everywhere in the northern Mozambique 38 

basement. The latter register large metamorphic overprint from Pan-African Orogeny on 39 

the older Mesoproterozoic basement, although with magmatic activity related to crustal 40 

reworking.  41 

The less pronounced populations between ca. 850-560 Ma together with 42 

paleoflow measurements allowed restricting the source areas when compared to a 43 

gathering of individual zircon age populations of the underlying basement. The older 44 

component refer to the bimodal magmatism related to the breakup phase of Rodinia 45 

Supercontinent registered in the Guro Suite which marks the western limit of the 46 

Moatize-Minjova rift basin. The ages between 630-560 compound the individual zircon 47 

ages of Guro Suite and SW Nampula although they are not attributed to a specific 48 

magmatic or metamorphic event.   49 



3 

 

The SW and NE Nampula Complexes must have being a unique geotectonic 50 

entity since Late Mesoproterozoic, reworked during Pan-African Orogeny. This allied to 51 

the N-NW paleoflow of Proto-Zambezi river and provenance data suggests that 52 

Nampula Complex was a probable high ground source area for fluvial sediments. 53 

Permian-Triassic rifting induced by far stress fields transferred from Gondwana margin 54 

have disrupted the Nampula Complex reactivating Precambrian structures and fabrics 55 

and the Jurassic-Cretaceous Gondwana breakup led to its actual morphology and 56 

configuration. 57 

 58 

Keywords: Precambrian-Cambrian basement, Pan-African Orogeny, Karoo 59 

Supergroup, Provenance 60 

 61 

1. Introduction  62 

U-Pb geochronology applied in detrital zircon grains is a powerful tool to 63 

understand provenance patterns in sedimentary basins (Fedo et al., 2003; Hartmann et 64 

al., 2008; Hawkesworth et al., 2010; Cawood, 2012; Bicca et al., 2013; Oliveira et al., 65 

2014; Bahlburg and Berndt, 2016). The age spectra constrained by this analysis reflect 66 

the tectonic setting of the basin in which the zircons are deposited (Cawood, 2012), 67 

assuming that the measured age distribution observed comprise an unbiased 68 

representation of the true age distribution in the sample and sedimentary unit it 69 

represents (Gehrels, 2014).  70 

Because zircon is resistant to abrasion and chemical alteration during 71 

sedimentary processes, the determination of the ages of detrital zircons indicates the 72 

timing of events in the source regions (Hartmann et al., 2008). An additional bias in 73 



4 

 

provenance studies is the variable abundance of zircons in source terrains (Moecher and 74 

Samson, 2006).  75 

The use of U-Pb dating by LA-ICP-MS technique to determine the ages of 76 

geological processes that formed the host rocks is a modern and common procedure in 77 

provenance investigation of sedimentary rocks (Hartmann et al., 2008; Guadagnin et al., 78 

2010; Thomas et al., 2010; Cawood, 2012; Bicca et al., 2013; Oliveira et al., 2014).  79 

In this paper we present a provenance analysis based on LA-ICPMS U-Pb ages 80 

of detrital zircon grains from a key immature coarse-sandstone of Matinde Formation 81 

from Karoo Supergroup, with specific focus on determine the denudation patterns of the 82 

Precambrian-Cambrian basement of northern Mozambique. The Late Carboniferous to 83 

Middle Jurassic volcano-sedimentary successions of the Karoo Supergroup (Smith, 84 

1993; Catuneanu et al., 2005) are widely distributed throughout south and central Africa 85 

hosted in marginal and intracontinental basins preserving  one of the largest registers of 86 

Gondwana evolution. In northwestern Mozambique they are represented by rift basin 87 

relying over the Precambrian basement rocks that were formed over a very long time 88 

span covering the Archean, Paleoproterozoic, Mesoproterozoic and Neoproterozoic, as 89 

the result of juvenile generation of crust, terrain accretion and crustal reworking during 90 

several orogenic cycles (Stern, 1994; Hanson, 2003; Meert, 2003; GTK Consortium, 91 

2006; Fritz et al., 2013; Macey et al., 2013; Grantham et al., 2013). A complex range of 92 

igneous and metamorphic ages, Th/U rates and zircon morphology suggest that main 93 

suturing, klippening and magmatism, related to the different stages of the protracted 94 

Pan-African orogenic cycle, controlled river catchment and provenance during Permian-95 

Triassic sedimentation.  96 

 97 

 98 



5 

 

2. Geological Settings  99 

The sedimentary basins of northwestern Mozambique comprise intracontinental 100 

rift basins filled by continental sediments and volcanic rocks from Karoo Supergroup 101 

and younger sequences. This basin relies over an important crustal structure, which 102 

correspond to an eastern extension of the Damara-Lufilian-Zambezi structure (Fig. 1).  103 

Crystalline basement of northwestern Mozambique is made of a very complex 104 

assemblage of igneous and low to high-grade metamorphic rocks, from distinct crustal 105 

levels, spanning from Mesoproterozoic to Neoproterozoic-Early Paleozoic in age 106 

(Hanson, 2003; Macey et al., 2013). Most Late Mesoproterozoic rocks have being 107 

reworked by the protracted Pan-African Orogeny in the later Neoproterozoic during 108 

Gondwana-assembly (Pinna et al., 1993; Sacchi et al., 2000), which occur in two main 109 

episodes at ca. 550 Ma and ca. 500 Ma (Ueda et al., 2012). Several studies developed in 110 

the north of Mozambique allow the definition of distinct crustal entities (Fig. 1), 111 

although, the geotectonic model still a matter of discussion (Pinna et al., 1993; Jacobs et 112 

al., 2008; Viola et al., 2008; Bingen et al., 2009; Ueda et al., 2012; Fritz et al., 2013; 113 

Macey et al., 2013).     114 

The north of Mozambique can by divided into two major Mesoproterozoic 115 

domains separated by the prominent Neoproterozoic–early Paleozoic Lurio Belt (Fig. 1) 116 

(Viola et al., 2008). This belt comprises a series of NE-anastomosing shear zones and is 117 

mostly represented by the granulite Ocua Complex, which occur mostly in the NE of 118 

Mozambique, while the SW segment of the Lurio Belt is partially undercovered (Fig. 1). 119 

U–Pb SIMS ages from selected latest-tectonic units in the Nampula Complex and the 120 

Lurio Belt give ages between 518 ± 2 and 514 ± 5 Ma, coeval with migmatisation and 121 

granitoid plutonism in the Nampula Complex (Ueda et al., 2012). The significance of 122 

the Lurio Belt is controversial. Some authors believe it represents a major suture zone 123 



6 

 

connecting with the Damara-Lufilian-Zambezi Belt (Sacchi et al., 2000; Grantham et 124 

al., 2003). Others suggest it is an accommodation zone, especially because of the 125 

similarities between metamorphic complexes north of the Lurio Belt with those of the 126 

Nampula Complex to the south (Viola et al., 2008; Bingen et al., 2009), an because of 127 

an apparent decrease in strain along the belt from NE to SW. 128 

The two domains north and south of the Lurio Belt share a similar 129 

Mesoproterozoic crustal growth history, although their evolution was diachronous. The 130 

Nampula Complex south of the belt developed between 1125 and 1035 Ma while the 131 

Unango and Marrupa Complexes to the north were between 1062 and 946 Ma. The 132 

maximum crustal thickening produced by Pan-African Orogeny in northeastern 133 

Mozambique occurred between ca. 570 and 530 Ma and later in the Nampula Complex 134 

(550–500 Ma) (Bingen et al., 2009; Macey et al., 2010; Thomas et al., 2010).  135 

The Unango and Marrupa Complexes are crustal domains made of large 136 

volumes of orthogneisses related to a continental arc setting (Bingen et al., 2009) and a 137 

minor magmatic phase at ca. 799 Ma registered in the Unango Complex. These 138 

complexes were overthrust at ca. 550 Ma by an assemblage of Neoproterozoic 139 

granulites of the Cabo Delgado nappes (including the Xixano, M’Sawize, Muaquia and 140 

Lalamo complexes), forming a stack of west vergent nappes (Viola et al., 2008; Bingen 141 

et al., 2009; Boyd et al., 2010; Macey et al., 2013).  142 

In northwestern Mozambique the Unango Complex overlies the small fault-143 

bounded Ponta Messuli Complex (Viola et al., 2008; Bingen et al., 2009), which 144 

contains Paleoproterozoic metasediments affected by migmatitization at around 1950 145 

Ma and intruded by granitic rocks at 1056 Ma. This complex is also overlain by the 146 

Neoproterozoic Txitonga Group which comprises a volcano-sedimentary complex with 147 

bimodal magmatism (Jacob et al., 2008). Westwards the Southern Irumide Belt is a 148 



7 

 

structurally and metamorphically complex region of mainly Mesoproterozoic igneous 149 

rocks related to a voluminous 1090–1040 Ma continental arc-related magmatic rocks, 150 

accompanied by high-temperature/low-pressure metamorphism (Fritz et al., 2013).  151 

Southern of the Lurio belt the Nampula Complex forms a large contiguous 152 

crustal block which consists of 1150–1030 Ma orthogneisses and metasedimentary 153 

rocks with high grade metamorphism around 1090–1030 Ma (Bingen et al., 2009; 154 

Macey et al., 2010). The ortogneisses from SW segment of the Nampula Complex (Fig. 155 

1) are interpreted as remnants of Mesoproterozoic continental magmatic arch (ca. 1100 156 

Ma; Chaúque, 2012). Over the Nampula Complex there are the tectonic emplaced 157 

Monapo and Mugeba granulite facies klippen that are assumed as equivalents of the 158 

Cabo Delgado nappes (Macey et al., 2007), considered to be erosional remnants of a 159 

larger and widespread nappe structure (Viola et al., 2008; Macey et al., 2013), which is 160 

improved by the absence of granulite-facies rocks in the underlying Nampula Complex. 161 

The Monapo Klippe consists dominantly of a mélange of granulite gneiss, deformed at 162 

634 ±8 Ma and intruded by ultramafic and mafic gneisses and alkaline granitic rocks 163 

(637 ± 5 Ma; Macey et al., 2013).  164 

These rocks are overlain by isolated Neoproterozoic metamorphosed molasse 165 

sediments (Fig. 1; Thomas et al., 2010; Chaúque, 2012). In the northeast section of NC 166 

the Mecubúri and Alto Benfica Groups are considered to be an autochthonous Cambrian 167 

meta-sedimentary cover of the Nampula Complex (Thomas et al., 2010). U–Pb analyses 168 

of detrital zircons from samples of the Mecubúri Group constrain a maximum 169 

deposition age of 530 ± 18 Ma, with zircon rims and metamorphic monazite grains 170 

dated at ca. 500 ± 10 and 499 ± 15 Ma respectively. Dating of detrital zircons from 171 

the Mecuburi Group indicate source rocks with ages peaking between ca. 1100–950 Ma, 172 



8 

 

750–800 Ma and 700–530 Ma, similar to the crystallisation ages in the Unango and 173 

Marrupa Complexes (Thomas et al., 2010). 174 

The southwest Nampula Complex (Fig. 2) is attributed to the frontal nappes of 175 

Chimoio-Macossa and Mungari Groups (Chaúque, 2012), consisting of low- to high-176 

grade paragneisses. The first is associated with the Barue magmatic arc represented by 177 

orthomagmatic rocks (ca. 1100 Ma; Fig. 2). These are in direct tectonic contact with the 178 

Kalahari cratonic rocks. The Mungari nappe includes the Guro Suite associations, which 179 

comprise abundant Neoproterozoic bimodal intrusive association (Fig. 2), characterize 180 

the east-dipping outer rim of the craton margin in the north (Chaúque et al., 2017). The 181 

felsic component dominantly consists of foliated aplitic granites, while the mafic one 182 

corresponds to metagabbro, locally deformed into mafic gneiss or schist with intruding 183 

pegmatite. Zircon grains from Granitic rocks indicate a magmatic crystallization age of 184 

867 ± 15 Ma. Dating of the nucleus of metamorphic zircons show recrystallization ages 185 

at ca. 850 – 839 Ma, related to extensional faulting, while the metamorphic rims 186 

provided an age of 512 ± 4 Ma related to the Pan-African Orogeny (GTK Consortium 187 

2006). At the northeastern margin of the cratonic area occur the low to medium grade 188 

metasedimentary and felsic metavolcanic (ca. 800 Ma) rocks of the Rushinga Group 189 

which may represent a passive margin of Neoproterozoic age (Barton et al., 1991; 190 

Hargrove et al., 2003; GTK Consortium 2006; Chaúque, 2012).  191 

Protracted collisional orogenesis was followed by the intrusion of late- to post 192 

tectonic Late Neoproterozoic granites (ca. 575-545Ma) and Cambrian-Ordovician K-193 

granites (ca. 530–495 Ma) (Macey et al., 2007; Jacobs et al., 2008; Ueda et al., 2012; 194 

Macey et al., 2013; Grantham et al., 2013). The latter is pronounced in the eastern 195 

Nampula Complex (Fig. 1) due to crustal delamination process that led to protract 196 

cooling history during Cambrian-Ordovician Times (Jacob et al., 2008; Emmel et al., 197 



9 

 

2014). These Precambrian-Cambrian basement rocks were partially covered by the 198 

Phanerozoic volcano-sedimentary deposits of the Karoo Supergroup and younger 199 

sequences (GTK Consortium, 2006).   200

2.1 Geology of the Matinde Formation  212 

The Matinde Formation generally comprises continental sedimentation during 213 

Permian-Triassic (mostly Triassic; Pereira et al., 2016) and represents one of the Karoo 214 

Supergroup deposits of northern Mozambique. This sequence is host in an NW-striking 215 

intracontinental rift basin, locally called as Moatize-Minjova Basin (Fig. 3). The rift 216 



11 

 

islimited by Precambrian structures and basin evolution follows distinct reactivation 217 

periods occurred in Phanerozoic times (Castaing, 1991; GTK Consortium, 2006; 218 

Fernandes et al., 2015; Bicca et al., 2017), under a transtensional stress regime 219 

associated with the NW-SE sinistral Zambezi pre-transform fault system (Castaing, 220 

1991; Bicca et al., 2017). The structural control over sedimentation is evidenced by 221 

depositional cycles of the Moatize and Matinde Formations.  222 

The Moatize Formation is made of interbedded carbonaceous mudstones, 223 

mudstones, rhythmites, sandstones and cyclic coal deposits (Cairncross, 2001; 224 

Lakshminarayana, 2015; Bicca et al., 2017) and its lithofacies assemblages are 225 

interpreted as a meandering fluvial system (Bicca et al., 2017). The coal beds represents 226 

thick peat deposits (ca. <40m) interbedded with very thick flood plain fines sequences 227 

(ca. <100m) (Fig. 4; Bicca et al., 2017). The absolute age of these coal-bearing 228 

formation is not well constrained and most comes from palynological record which 229 

suggests a Lower to Middle Permian age for the top part of the Moatize Formation 230 

(Daber, 1984). Although, Pereira et al. (2014) founded a Kungurian/Roadian age 231 

(Lower – Middle Permian) for the basal sequences of the Moatize Formation, 232 

positioning its depositional cycle throughout the Early-Late Permian.  233 

Overlaying the Moatize Formation there are mostly cross-bedded coarse-grained 234 

alluvial deposits from the Matinde, its being assumed a depositional age close to the 235 

Permian-Triassic boundary but most of the depositional cycle relies in the Triassic 236 

period (Pereira et al., 2016). This formation is attributed to a braided fluvial plain 237 

system mostly represented by coarse to conglomeratic red sandstones (Fig. 4). Planar 238 

and through-cross bedding are the most common structures, separated in sets of ca. 0.5 239 

to 2 meters by planar surfaces (GTK Consortium, 2006; Bicca et al., 2017). Lithofacies 240 

associations and its internal relationship suggest deposition of poorly channelized 241 



12 

 

braided alluvial plain in which downstream and probably lateral accretion macroforms 242 

alternates with gravity flow deposits (Bicca et al., 2017). Northwestwards paleoflow 243 

from Moatize and Matinde lithofacies suggest that the Zambezi River flow was inverted 244 

during Permian sedimentation in northern Mozambique, with its headwaters located in 245 

the southeastern highland areas, inherited from the Pan-African Orogeny (Key et al., 246 

2015; Bicca et al., 2017).  247

3. Methods 264 

We collected one sample from a coarse-sandstone of Matinde Formation 265 

exposed in the study area at coordinates 16°12'22.57"S and 33°34'5.09"E (Fig. 3 and 266 

Fig. 4). The outcrop is the top of a 300 m high profile that has thick (1–2 m) sets of 267 

coarse-sandstones and conglomerates with a fining upward pattern. This sequence 268 

marks an important process of rejuvenation in the source area, as indicated by the 269 

Permian-Triassic depositional pattern (Fig. 4) and show excellent levels of outcrop 270 

preservation in terms of weathering, tectonic and any hydrothermal processes, difficult 271 

to find in the region. In addition, more mature sandstones tend to does not preserve 272 

metamorphic overgrowths due to abrasion during transport (Hartmann and Santos, 273 

2004). 274 

Mineral separation was carried out at Rio Grande do Sul Federal University, 275 

using standard procedures of crushing the rock, milling and sieving. Zircons were 276 

separated using conventional heavy liquids and magnetic procedures, hand-picked and 277 

mounted on an epoxy disc, together with CZ3 (564 Ma) zircon standards and polished 278 

to expose their internal surfaces.  279 

U-Pb analysis was performed with laser-ablation multi-collector inductively 280 

coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-MC-ICP-MS) at São Paulo University. All 281 

grains used for zircon dating were imaged with cathodoluminescence to determine their 282 

internal structures and crystallization phases (to support spot location and age 283 

interpretation). Only zircon grains free of imperfections such as fractures and mineral 284 

inclusions were selected for analysis (Fig. 5). The analytical conditions and data 285 

reduction for the LA-MC-ICPMS method were identical to those described by Chemale 286 

Jr. et al. (2011). Isoplot 3 software (Ludwig, 2003) was used to generate the concordia 287 

diagrams and histograms. For the concordia age calculations and frequency histograms, 288 



15 

 

only the analysis with 100 ± 10% of concordance was included. The U-Pb detrital 289 

zircon analytical data are show in Table 1. Corrections for common Pb were made using 290 

measured 
204

Pb and the Pb isotopic composition. Results with more than 1% common 291 

Pb correction were not use to calculate the ages. Confidence limits (90%) were 292 

compiled for pooled ages and one sigma limits for individual zircons.  Ages older than 293 

1.5 Ga are express as weighed mean

4. Results 315 

Cathodoluminescence (CL) imaging of 64 zircon crystals (Fig. 6) indicate size 316 

variation from 100 to 300 ?m, but most crystals are 100–200 ?m. Some crystals show 317 

rounded hedges, but many have irregular shapes; this is consistent with the immature nature 318 

of the coarse-sandstone. Rounding of the crystals was attributed to two processes: i) 319 

sedimentary abrasion during transport, and ii) preserved metamorphic rims and 320 

overgrowths (Fig. 5). The internal textures of the crystals is very complex, with cores often 321 

showing oscillatory zoning, surrounded by one or more metamorphic rims or recrystallized 322 

zoned patterns. Sector-zoned, relatively homogeneous grains as well as grains with more 323 

complex textures also occur. Chaotic textures are common trends in zircons from granulite 324 

facies rocks. Concentric zoning, when present, is rather irregular and resembles only 325 

weakly the parallel or regular geometry of zoned magmatic zircon. Distinct age populations 326 

could be identifying in the core and in metamorphic rims ranging from Late 327 

Mesoproterozoic to Cambrian times (Tab. 1 and Fig. 5). 328 

 329 

Figure 5: Cathodoluminescence image of some zircon grains that are representative of the 330 

analytical results using LA-ICP-MS. The spots and measured U-Pb ages (Ma) are indicated. 331 



20 

 

The older age component is represented by 19 zircon grains providing Late 332 

Mesoproterozoic ages (1,005 ± 17Ma to 1,130 ± 20Ma) with a concordant age of 1040 ± 333 

4.9 Ma (N = 7) (Fig. 6). Th/U ratios of these grains are very distinct ranging from 0.09 to 334 

1.57, which is related to the U content of each zircon grain varying from 22 to 356 ppm 335 

(Tab. 1), being the highest Th/U ratios related to an increasing in the U and Th 336 

concentrations. The zircons of this population are commonly rounded fragments of crystal, 337 

but some preserve part of its prismatic form (Fig. 5). Well-developed thin oscillatory 338 

zoning occur in several grains, sometimes surrounding earlier crystallization phases with no 339 

internal texture. Homogeneous metamorphic rims are also preserved in a few grains. 340 

A second population of zircon ages constraining the Early-Middle Neoproterozoic 341 

times (859 ± 11Ma to 992 ± 20Ma) were identified from 5 zircon grains (Fig. 7), but did 342 

not allow to define a concordia age. These grains show distinct internal textures indicating 343 

well developed magmatic oscillatory growth in two crystals (Fig. 5). One crystal is 344 

prismatic, but with no evident internal texture and one fragment of zircon showing sector-345 

zoning with two clear compositionally distinct areas, probably derived from a high-grade 346 

metamorphic rocks (Fig. 5). A last zircon show two homogeneous recrystallization zones 347 

around a elongated lighted nucleus evidencing a probable heritage zircon core. Th-U ratios 348 

are between 0.20 to 0.99, while the U content range from 65 to 338 ppm (Tab. 1), which we 349 

interpreted as magmatic ages, assuming the premises described above.     350 

The younger age component from our data comprises the Late Neoproterozoic – 351 

Cambrian ages, from 637 ± 8 Ma to 493 ± 5Ma. This age population is registered in 21 352 

zircon grains that show oscillatory growing and less metamorphic rims. 353 

Cathodoluminescence imaging reveals both sector-zoned cores with thin overgrowths and 354 

oscillatory zoned cores (Fig. 5). Local zircon resorption and reprecipitation, patchy zoning 355 



21 

 

and fractures disrupting original zoning and filled by zircon with low-trace elements 356 

composition (Corfu et al., 2003; Fig. 5) are also observed. Three main peak ages could be 357 

distinguished from this age component: (1) from 8 zircon grains we determine a magmatic 358 

concordia age of 609.8 ± 3.4 Ma; (2) Six grains define a concordia age of 553.8 ± 3.9 Ma 359 

referring to zircons with oscillatory growth; (3) An younger concordant age of 501.6 ± 2.3 360 

Ma constrained from seven zircon grains mark the late high grade metamorphism of the 361 

Pan-African Orogeny (Fig. 6). Th-U ratios are between 0.07 to 1.12 while the U content 362 

ranges from 47 to 582 ppm (Tab. 1). These concentrations suggest that the ages obtained 363 

are mostly magmatic, but a few grains that present Th/U ratios around 0.1, could be related 364 

to metamorphic processes involved into their generation (Hartmann and Santos, 2004). 365

 373 

5. Interpretation 374 

The detrital zircon age spectra observed in the sample showed only older age’s with 375 

respect to the depositional age that reflect the history of the underlying basement as 376 

expected in intracratonic settings (Cawood et al., 2012). Zircon morphology, internal 377 



23 

 

textures and ages provide insights into the geotectonic history of the underlying basement, 378 

allowing the definition of four main age groups: i) 1,130-1,005 Ma; ii) 992-859 Ma; iii) 379 

637-563 Ma; and iv) 549-493 Ma. The former and the latter are the most prominent 380 

provenances of the Karoo sediments, highlighting two important events of crustal 381 

generation, consumption and deformation of Rodinia and Gondwana (Pan-African 382 

Orogeny) Supercontinents.   383 

Paleocurrent measurements indicate an N-NW paleoflow for the fluvial sequences 384 

of the Matinde Formation (Bicca et al., 2017). Since we collected immature sandstone, the 385 

probable source areas are located somewhere in the south of the Moatize-Minjova Basin, 386 

less then ca.200km (Hartmann et al., 2004) due to the preservation of the metamorphic 387 

rims. 388 

The first and older age group reflects the greater crustal component in the north of 389 

Mozambique. They mostly reflect magmatic crystallization ages as evidenced by 390 

oscillatory grown in the zircon grains, which are a common feature in this population. Late 391 

Mesoproterozoic was an important moment of crustal generation everywhere in the distinct 392 

terrenes of northern Mozambique. These age spectrum falls in the age range of the Barue 393 

Magmatic Arch (SW Nampula; Fig. 7), as also, in the provenance record of the Chimoio-394 

Macossa (SW Nampula) and Mungari nappes, which in turn received sediments from the 395 

Báruè Magmatic Arch (Chaúque, 2012).   396 

The ages between ca. 950 and 550 Ma do not present very wide distribution and 397 

correspond to important periods of crustal geotectonic evolution in the north of 398 

Mozambique. Manjate (2011) reports an U-Pb metamorphic age at 956 ± 38 Ma (MSWD = 399 

0.39) for the orthogneisses of SW Nampula and Grantham et al. (2011) found an age of 400 

996.8 Ma ± 3.4 Ma (MSWD = 2.3) for a migmatitic vain of the Chimoio Group 401 



24 

 

(paragneisses of SW Nampula). Similar ages are observed as metamorphic ages around ca. 402 

940 Ma in the Unango and Marrupa Complexes (Bingen et al., 2009). Nevertheless, the 403 

zircon ages clusters the data of Manjate (2015) for the Guro Suite/Mungari Garnet Granite 404 

Migmatite/Chacocoma Granite zircon dating (Fig. 7). These suggests that Early 405 

Neoproterozoic population ages probably represents a late magmatic and metamorphic 406 

event associated to Rodinia amalgamation processes present in the Mesoproterozoic 407 

basement rocks (Jacobs et al., 2008; Macey et al., 2013). On the other hand, the 408 

crystallization ages around ca. 860 and 820 Ma (GTK Consortium, 2006; Chaúque, 2012; 409 

Manjate, 2015) are positioned near a extension tectonic period and emplacement of the 410 

protoliths of the Guro Suite, which possess a positive ?nd suggesting a strong mantle 411 

contribution (Chaúque, 2012) and are related to the breakup of Rodinia Supercontinent. The 412 

Mozambique Ocean closed during a protracted period of island-arc and microcontinent 413 

accretion between ca. 850 and 620 Ma (Fritz et al., 2013).  414 

The ages around ca. 630 and 560 Ma refers to distinct events of deformation and 415 

magmatism along the north of Mozambique basement. They are registered in the Monapo 416 

Klippe (ca. 635 Ma), and interpreted as a major episode of granulite-facies metamorphism 417 

and crust generation (Macey et al., 2013). SHRIMP zircon data from samples from alkaline 418 

intrusions and mafic granulites in the same complex yield crystallization and metamorphic 419 

ages of ca. 635 Ma and 570-590 Ma, respectively (Grantham et al., 2013).  420 

The Cabo Delgado Nappe Complex (north of the Lurio Belt) was an extended crust 421 

that formed adjacent to the Mozambique Ocean and experienced a ca. 650–620Ma 422 

granulite-facies metamorphism (Fritz et al., 2013). They are also found in the Ocua 423 

Complex, which contains high-P granulite boudins dated at 557 ± 16 Ma, evidence for 424 

deformation at least until 532 ± 13 Ma and abundant on 612 ± 6 to 504 ± 11 Ma felsic 425 



25 

 

plutons (Norconsult Consortium, 2007). Evidence of the closure of the Mozambique Ocean 426 

is present on data from other sections of the East Africa Orogen indicated by accretion of 427 

various volcanic arc and microcontinent fragments onto the margin of the Congo-Tanzania 428 

Craton between 655 and 610 Ma (Meert, 2003; Collins and Pisarevsky, 2005; Jöns and 429 

Schenk, 2008; Bingen et al., 2007). This age population is not strongly impressed in the 430 

SW Nampula Complex and Guro Suite/Mungari Garnet Granite Migmatite/Chacocoma 431 

Granite although they are present in the individual zircon ages presented by Chaúque 432 

(2012) and Manjate (2015), but enough to correlate with our data. Additionally, the 433 

provenance analyzes in the Alto-Benfica and Mecuburi Neoproterozoic-Cambrian basins in 434 

detrital zircons using the U-Pb method (NE Mozambique, Thomas et al., 2010) indicated a 435 

strong contribution of the northern Marrupa and Unango Complexes. The Mecuburi Group 436 

present a high contribution of zircon dated at ca. 600 Ma however, they are practically 437 

absent from Alto-Benfica age populations. The latter, show some ages > 1200 Ma (Thomas 438 

et al., 2010), suggesting that the Moatize-Minjova Basin has a distinct provenance, since 439 

these ages were not verified in their zircons.  440 

After the events of crustal thickening and klippening resulting from the Pan-African 441 

Orogeny (ca. 550-480 Ma), the southern region of the Moatize-Minjova Basin probably 442 

formed a topographic high along with the entire NE portion of Mozambique. These sites 443 

have probably originated the headwaters of the rivers and tributaries that bathed the Proto-444 

Zambezi basin, as suggested by Key et al. (2015) and Bicca et al. (2017). The ages 445 

contained between ca. 550 and 480 Ma are attributed to magmatic and metamorphic events 446 

common in the region due to high-grade metamorphism produced by Pan-African Orogeny 447 

and therefore are not good markers for determining sedimentary provenance (Fig. 7).  448 



26 

 

The concentrations and rates of Th/U of our data compared with a few available 449 

data from underlying assemblages interpreted as the main source region for the sediments 450 

allow defining some correlations. The NE Nampula Th/U rates are comparable to ours, but 451 

Th/U rates of <0.1 were attribute to a metamorphic origin (Hartmann and Santos, 2004) as 452 

also the very high U concentrations (> 1000 ppm) which are reasonable common in that 453 

area and were not observed in the zircons from Matinde Formation (Fig. 8). This 454 

comparison strengthens the correlation of Matinde Formation sediments with SW Nampula 455 

Complex rocks, which has compositional characteristics close to those obtained in the 456 

Moatize-Minjova Basin zircons (Fig. 8). 457

the basin and were compiled from Chaúque (2012) and Manjate (2015). 462

Figure 8: Relationship between U content and Th/U rates for the NE and NW Nampula 464 

complexes and of the Guro Suite. The dark line highlights the 0.1 limit of Th/U rates and 465 

light gray areas represent the less pronounced concentrations U concentrations in our data. 466 

 467 

6. Conclusion 468 

Provenance data from U-Pb LA-ICPMS dating of detrital zircon crystals showed to 469 

be as a reliable analytical technique to map sediment source regions from ancient fold and 470 

thrust belts underlying sedimentary basin. This information unveils to be relevant to 471 

reestablish the paleogeography allowing identifying the probable configuration of basement 472 

relief near this intracontinental rift. The choice of the sample in relation to the sand 473 

granulometry and tectono-stratigraphic relevance, allow obtaining a more comprehensive 474 

information of the magmatic and metamorphic processes in the northern Mozambique. A 475 

detailed and systematic analysis of zircon morphology and internal textures, U-Pb ages and 476 

Th/U rates allows defining the SW Nampula and the Guro Suite/Mungari Garnet Granite 477 

Migmatite/Chacocoma Granite (W-SW of the basin) as the main source areas during 478 

Permian Triassic sedimentation in our sample from the Moatize-Minjova Basin. The data 479 

revealed a strong contribution of Late Mesoproterozoic ages, which constrain the greater 480 

magmatic and metamorphic ages of the basement from northern Mozambique. A Late 481 



28 

 

Neoproterozoic-Cambrian age population, reflecting magmatic and high metamorphic ages, 482 

was provided by the large overprint of the Pan-African Orogeny. Nevertheless, it was the 483 

less pronounced zircon grain ages that allowed restricting a narrower source region.  484 

The ages between ca. 950 Ma to 550 Ma are not prominent in northwestern 485 

Mozambique basement rocks, especially ages around ca 630-600 Ma. This moment refer to 486 

a distinct period of high-grade metamorphism and little magmatism associated with the 487 

closure of the Mozambique Ocean and mostly preserved in Cabo Delgado, Mugeba and 488 

Monapo Klippens of NE Mozambique. However, they are present as individual zircon ages 489 

in the SW Nampula Complex and Guro Suite/Mungari Garnet Granite 490 

Migmatite/Chacocoma Granite associations, which must have being the major source area 491 

for the Moatize-Minjova Basin during Permian-Triassic sedimentation. The ages between 492 

ca. 950 and 820 Ma are also well documented in the established provenance region. 493 

Further investigations are needed to improve our data and map local and regional 494 

variations in provenance pattern in different stratigraphic levels and sites in all the Karoo 495 

basins from northern Mozambique. These would allow a more precise definition of 496 

paleogeomorphology evolution of the Precambrian-Cambrian basement rocks through 497 

Phanerozoic. 498

Abstract 26 

The southern African plate has underwent several processes of horizontal and 27 

vertical stress since Permian times attributed to Gondwanides orogenesis and to mantle 28 

plumes upwelling from the Gondwana separation stages, respectively. Since about 30 29 

Ma the plume related to the East Africa Rift system affects the NE Africa leading to the 30 

development of topographically high lands affecting denudation history in all region.  31 

The NW Mozambique central apatite fission track ages range from Mesozoic to 32 

Cenozoic times and an accumulated denudation thickness of about 2 - 3.5 km since 33 

Upper Triassic times. The very early denudation stages of NW Mozambique were 34 

marked by very low and local denudation rates (1-10 m/Ma) reaching about to 500 m 35 

thick of eroded material until Lower Cretaceous. The larges amonts have being eroded 36 

from since Lower Cretaceous with rates of 3-17 m/Ma until Middle Paleocene when 37 

high denudation rates of 31-47 m/Ma bring the samples to the present conditions.  38 

The early cooling events are associated with erosion produced by extensional / 39 

transtractive processes associated with the early break-up stages of Gondwana recorded 40 

in several rift basins with thick volcano-sedimentary sequences from Karoo Supergroup. 41 

This period also marks the drift of Madagascar through the Davie Fracture Zone from 42 

the coast of Tanzania to the coast of Mozambique and the opening of the Mozambique 43 

and Somalia basins. The Upper Jurassic and Upper Cretaceous were a period of great 44 

development of the Indian ocean and the start of the N-S drift of Antarctica in relation 45 

to the African plate marked in most of the maximum paleotemperatures observed in the 46 

region.  47 

From Lower Cretaceous to Paleocene high amounts of denudation was attributed 48 

to the development of the African margin and the reconfiguration of inland drainage 49 

patterns. A significant increase of the cooling rates (1.17 to 0.88 °C/Ma) implying in the 50 



3 

 

denudation of about 1.5 to 2 km thick from the beginning of the Neogene to the Recent 51 

times. These cooling event was related to dynamic topography induced by the East 52 

African Rift mantle plume upwelling, which has been active since the Paleogene period.  53 

 54 

Keywords: Apatite Fission Track, NW Mozambique, Denudation rates, East Africa Rift 55 

System, Gondwana break-up 56 

 57 

1. Introduction  58 

The architecture of the continental margin of northern Mozambique shows a 59 

close relationship to pre-existing Pan-African structures of the East African–Antarctic 60 

Orogen (Jacobs and Thomas, 2004; Fig. 1A) which plays an important role in margin 61 

configuration and landscape evolution (Emmel et al., 2011). Several crustal 62 

readjustments were observed during Phanerozoic period registered as brittle/ductile 63 

structures and sedimentation patterns all over south-central Africa (Catuneanu et al., 64 

2005). Gondwana break-up was preceded by intracontinental Permian-Triassic rifting, 65 

marked by the deposition of thick sequences of Karoo Supergroup along south-central 66 

Africa (Catuneanu et al., 2005; Bicca et al., 2017), ending with a magmatic event (basalt 67 

flows) that took place during the final phase of Gondwana stability between 205 and 68 

175 Ma (Salman and Abdula, 1995). After that, the opening of the Indian Ocean sea 69 

floor was marked by the southward drifting of the East Antarctica/Madagascar/India 70 

Seychelles block guided by the Davie transform fault  (Fig. 1B) away from East Africa 71 

between ca. 158 and 119 Ma (Salman and Abdula, 1995; Emmel et al., 2014).  72 

The ongoing of Gondwana break-up led to the high denudation rates on the East 73 

Africa - Antarctica Orogen (Daszinnies et al., 2009; Emmel et al., 2011; Emmel et al., 74 

2014; Bauer et al., 2016) and provide the development of distinct onshore and offshore 75 



4 

 

basins along east Africa passive margin. These basins are mostly filled with sediments 76 

discharged since Jurassic times (post-Gondwana disruption) over Karoo igneous rocks 77 

(Salman and Abdula, 1995; Reeves, 2000; Mahanjane, 2012; Castelino et al., 2015). 78 

The study of exhumation and landscape evolution of Precambrian belts using 79 

low temperature thermochronological methods has become a robust tool for the 80 

improvement of regional tectonic models. With this in mind we used  the apatite fission-81 

track dating method to reconstruct the low-temperature cooling history (120–60 °C) of 82 

the Precambrian basement rocks of northwestern and central Mozambique  (Fig. 1C). 83 

The aim of this study was to identify distinct denudation patterns on the hinterland 84 

determining the thermal ages and denudation rates of the Precambrian basement 85 

associations which contributed to sedimentation of intracratonic rift basins and with the 86 

depositional history in the north of Mozambique Basin. Therefore, we collected 27 rock 87 

samples from Mozambican shield, distributed comprehensively in the whole area in 88 

order to understand all regional structures and geotectonic domains identifying all 89 

differential denudation patterns. 90 

 91 

2. Geological Settings  92 

The northern and central region of Mozambique comprises a wide range of 93 

Precambrian and Cambrian igneous and metamorphic rocks formed in two distinct 94 

orogenic periods concerning the formation of the Rodinia and Gondwana 95 

Supercontinents (Norconsult Consortium, 2007). These associations can be subdivided 96 

into a northern, central and a southern provinces, by a series of E-W, N-S and NW-SE 97 

ductile crustal scale structures reactivated in a brittle regime during the Phanerozoic, 98 

caused by far compressive stress fields in the south-southwestern margin of Gondwana 99 



5 

 

(Fig. 1C; Castaing, 1991; Salman and Abdula, 1995; Norconsult Consortium, 2007; 100 

Bicca et al., 2017). 101 

The south and central provinces are delimited by an ENE-trending structure 102 

attributed as a probable southern continuation of the Lurio Belt and the Sanangoe Shear 103 

Zone (Fig. 1C) (Norconsult Consortium, 2007; Jacobs et al., 2008; Viola et al., 2008; 104 

Bingen et al., 2009; Ueda et al., 2012). The ENE-trending structure converge 105 

southwards and mark the tectonic contact between the Southern Nampula Complex and 106 

the Kalahari Craton associations (Chaúque et al., 2017).  107 

In the central area there are mostly Neoproterozoic ortho- and paragneisses 108 

which protoliths are related to juvenile magmatism of Rodinia break-up and marginal 109 

sedimentary basins deformed and thrust during Pan-African Orogeny (Chaúque, 2012; 110 

Manjate, 2015). These associations are surrounded by the sequences of the Karoo 111 

Supergroup (Late Carboniferous - Middle Jurassic) that comprises continental 112 

sediments and a bimodal magmatism erupted between 195-180 Ma attributed to an early 113 

aborted stage of Gondwana breakup (Salman and Abdula, 1995; Reeves, 2000) and 114 

younger igneous and sedimentary sequences related to the post-break-up period (Late 115 

Jurassic - Recent). They are hosted into E-W and NW-SE rift basins that compound the 116 

Zambezi Valley basins drained by the Zambezi River and its tributaries comprise one of 117 

the greater actual fluvial systems of Africa (Castaing, 1991; Norconsult Consortium, 118 

2007; Fernandes et al., 2015; Bicca et al., 2017). The Zambezi delta is responsible for 119 

carry sediments into the offshore Mozambique Basin (Fig. 1B).  120 

The Sanangoe Shear Zone (SSZ) cut off the study area over a distance of about 121 

350 km (Fig. 1C) and represents a probable Pan-African connection between West and 122 

South Gondwana (Fig. 1A; Macey et al., 2013). In the north of this structure occur the 123 

Southern Irumide Belt (Fritz et al., 2013) comprising a large land mass of 124 



6 

 

Mesoproterozoic association intruded by Late Neoproterozoic granitoids and 125 

structurally overprinted by Pan-African Orogeny. Just south of the Sanangoe Shear 126 

Zone there is a large and merely NW-SE elongated segment of the Southern Irumide 127 

Belt  that corresponds to a stratiform gabbro-anorthositic association tectonically 128 

transported with a SE-vergent during Pan-African Orogeny.  129 

The great structures were affected by brittle reactivations under a sinistral 130 

transtensional regime induced by compressive stress fields in south-southwest 131 

Gondwana margin propagating throw NW-SE Zambezi pre-transform fault system from 132 

Late-Carboniferous to Middle Triassic.  These reactivations are registered by periods of 133 

intense subsidence in the related rift basins generating great accommodation space for 134 

sedimentation and controlling depositional patterns and Mesozoic magmatic events 135 

(Castaing, 1991; Bicca et al., 2017). After that, the Gondwana break up led to large 136 

sedimentation patterns and tectonics within the extensional sedimentary basins along 137 

the east African margin basins which mostly show a continuous post-Jurassic record of 138 

sediment deposition (Salman and Abdula, 1995), reflecting high denudation histories in 139 

the onshore Mozambique basement (Salman and Abdula, 1995; Reeves, 2000; 140 

Mahanjane, 2012; Castelino et al., 2015).   141 



7 

 

 142

the locations of the East African Orogen and Kuunga Orogen shown. B) Gondwana at 144 

ca. 140 Ma after the initial break-up between Madagascar and East Africa with Karoo 145

 149 

The Mozambique Basin (MB) covers the onshore and offshore parts of central 150 

and southern areas of the Mozambique margin (Fig. 1B). The MB comprises one of the 151 

oldest extensional sedimentary basins developed along the eastern African margin and 152 

the stratigraphic record of the basin is dominated by marine deposits changing gradually 153 

from deepest to shallower through time (Castelino et al., 2015). This basin registers a 154 

Mesozoic sedimentation of  5-10 cm/kyr and 1-3 cm/kyr rates during Paleogene being 155 



8 

 

the former associated with high subsidence rates in the basin until Early Cretaceous 156 

times. The decrease in sedimentation rates from ca. 140 Ma until ca. 90 Ma is attributed 157 

to tectonic uplift in the onshore African basement which in consequence led to its rapid 158 

denudation increasing in the sediment influx into the basin until ca. 60 Ma. This uplift 159 

would be related to an epeirogenic event with Kimberlite emplacement in the African 160 

continent (Patridge and Maud, 1987). Another period of low sedimentation rates occur 161 

in the Low Paleogene attributed to a sediment-starved basin during a relative quiet 162 

tectonic phase onshore, but a tectonic uplift in the onshore basement around 30 Ma 163 

leading to another fast exhumation period onshore high sedimentation rates until 164 

Quaternary (Castelino et al., 2015).  165 

 166 

2.1 Thermochronological Constraints 167 

In the NW region of Mozambique apatite fission track (AFT) data are restricted 168 

to the Moatize-Minjova Basin which hosts the volcano-sedimentary sequences of Karoo 169 

Supergroup and also younger volcano-sedimentary sequences (Fig. 2). Four samples 170 

from two wells (ca. 500 m each) of the sedimentary rocks of Karoo Supergroup were 171 

analyzed providing a geothermal paleogradiente of 40 ° C/ km and apatite fission track 172 

ages between 146 to 84 Ma (Ferrnandes et al., 2015). According to the models, peak 173 

burial temperatures were attained shortly after deposition (3-10 Ma) and indicates two 174 

episodes of cooling and exhumation. The first between 240 and 230 Ma implying 2500 175 

and 3000 m of denudation, while the second from 6 Ma onwards implying 1000 and 176 

1500 m of denudation. The first denudation period was attributed to tectonic 177 

reactivation related to the Cape Fold Belt in South Africa and the latter to the southward 178 

propagation of the East African Rift System into Mozambique (Ferrnandes et al., 2015). 179 



9 

 

On the other hand, in the NE Mozambique there are a large spectrum of 180 

thermochronometric data for the basement provinces north and south of the Lurio Belt 181 

(Fig. 2; Daszinnies, 2006; Daszinnies et al., 2009; Emmel et al., 2011; Bauer et al., 182 

2016). According to these data the region underwent differential post-orogenic thermal 183 

history (Emmel et al., 2011) as defined from titanite, zircon and apatite fission track 184 

data. The first two fission track methods provided ages north of the Lurio Belt ranging 185 

between ca. 578 Ma and 310 Ma, while in the south they are constrained between ca. 186 

460 Ma and 219 Ma. Apatite fission track analisys from samples in the north provide 187 

ages between ca. 326 Ma and 91 Ma contrasting with younger ages to south (147 to 59 188 

Ma; Fig. 2), suggesting that the southern province experience highest exhumation rates 189 

during Gondwana break-up. Thermal ages determine that the northern basement 190 

characterize rapid post orogenic cooling and exhumed to present levels during the 191 

Paleozoic, although the southern basement only underwent slow post-orogenic cooling. 192 

(Emmel et al., 2011).  193 

Aditionally, thermal activitie during Cretaceous times was also described by Eby 194 

et al. (1995) studing the Cretaceous Chilwa Alkaline Province of southern Malawi (Fig. 195 

2). These authors presented K-Ar in amphibole and titanite fission-track ages indicating 196 

that igneous activity occurred in distinct periods starting at ca. 133 Ma with thermal 197 

igneous activity ending at ca. 113 Ma with the emplacement of large syenite-peralkaline 198 

granite plutons. The apatite fission-track ages and track-length measurements indicated 199 

that the emplacement of the large syenite-granite pluton caused local doming, leading to 200 

a rapid exhumation rate. However, more distal plutons show a slower cooling rate, 201 

suggesting that they were on the flanks of the local uplift and more deeply buried. These 202 

authors interpreted the Chilwa magmatism produced by crustal extension which 203 

reactivate pre-existing orogenic anisotropies leading to decompressional melting. 204 



10 

 

Similar K-Ar ages are described by alcaline rocks in NW Mozambique lying between 205 

ca. 106-166 Ma (GTK Consortion, 2006). 206 

Further north of the study area, Van der Beek et al. (1998) identified from AFT 207 

data, fast cooling and denudation processes on the flanks of Malawi and Rukwa rifts 208 

(Fig. 2) during the periods of 250-200 Ma, ca. 150 Ma and ? 40-50 Ma. These present 209 

correlation with different sedimentation and rifting processes in the basin associated to 210 

the rift, where erosion, tectonic and isostatic rebound would be responsible for the 211 

reconfiguration of the surface during these events. The first interval corresponds to the 212 

final processes of erosion and deposition of the Karoo Supergroup, while in ca. 150 Ma 213 

occurs a reactivation of the rift separating Gondwana. Finally, the event between ? 40-214 

50 Ma was interpreted as the result of the flexural isostatic response of the lithosphere 215 

to extensional unloading during rifting. 216 

Through the Limpopo Belt (at the south of the study area, Fig. 2; Belton and 217 

Haab, 2010) extensive regions experienced kilometer-scale exhumation at around 130 218 

Ma and 90 Ma (Fig. 2). These period maks the strike–slip motion of the local fault 219 

patterns in this region due to the breakup of Gondwana as also igneous intrusions at ca. 220 

120 Ma and ca. 90 Ma and demonstrated that the sedimentation and subsidence rates on 221 

the Mozambique margin are in agreement with this data. 222 



11

sample locations for this study and previous works.   225

3. Methods  227 

We have applied apatite fission track thermochronology technique on 27 228 

samples from Precambrian basement rocks of NW Mozambique assemblages as 229 

indicated in Figure 1, and their lithological characteristics are listed in Table 1. The 230 

samples were collected in an area that comprehensively covers the main tectonic 231 

domains of the northwestern and central regions of Mozambique at distinct altitudes 232 

ranging from 217 to 843 m (Tab. 1 and Fig. 3A).  233 



12 

 

The analytical procedures were performed at Rio Grande do Sul Federal 234 

University. The apatite grains were concentrated by conventional magnetic, heavy 235 

liquid and hand-picking techniques and mounted in epoxy resin. Afterwards, the mounts 236 

were polished and etched, using 5.5 M HNO3 at 21 ºC for 20s to reveal the spontaneous 237 

fission tracks (Ketcham et al., 2007). The apatite mounts were covered with mica sheets 238 

to obtain the fission track ages using the external detector method (Gleadow, 1981). 239 

Neutron irradiation was performed at the FRM-II reactor in Garching (TU München, 240 

Germany). After irradiation, the mica detectors were etched with 48% HF for 18 min to 241 

reveal the induced fission tracks.  242 

Fission-track counting was performed with a Leica DM6000 Microscope at 243 

1000x magnification. The fission track ages were calculated using the zeta calibration 244 

approach (Hurford, 1990) with CN5 dosimeter glass and the Durango apatite age 245 

standard. At least 20 grains were counted per sample; while 100 horizontal confined 246 

tracks were measured for the track length distribution (Gleadow et al., 1986; Gallagher 247 

et al., 1998), as its orientation relative to the c-axis. Commonly a hundred or more 248 

confined tracks were observed and measured in the samples, but some did not have the 249 

same abundance. Yet we decided to retain them nonetheless due to their agreement with 250 

the nearby samples that do have good-quality measurements.  The ages are expressed as 251 

central ages with percent variation (Galbrait and Lasllet, 1993). Throughout this study, 252 

fission track age errors are quoted at the 1? confidence level and were derived by the 253 

conventional method (Green, 1981). For each apatite grain analyzed, a mean value for 254 

the kinetic parameter Dpar (Donelick et al., 2005) was determined from five 255 

measurements. The ?2 -squared test was used to quantify age homogeneity (Galbraith 256 

and Laslett, 1993) using the software “RadialPlotter” (Vermeesch, 2009).  257 



13 

 

Thermal history modeling was carried out using the QTQt software (Gallagher, 258 

2012) with the multi-kinetic annealing model of Ketcham et al. (2007). The priors on 259 

the general time-temperature were set by the software based on the ages observed in 260 

each sample. Each inversion model was run at 100,000 Burnin and 100,000 Post-burn-261 

in iterations to provide more stable solutions (see discussion in Gallagher, 2012). 262 

Denudation histories were based on geothermal gradients estimated for the African 263 

plate. We assume a constant and linear geothermal gradient over geological times and 264 

suppose that the geothermal gradient is linear (25 °C/km; Martinelli et al., 1995). 265 

 266 

4. Results  267 

AFT ages and confined mean track length (MTL) measurements from the 268 

basement samples are presented in Table 1. The central AFT ages do not present a clear 269 

correlation with the altitude sampled and no vertical profile match was obteined, 270 

suggesting that these samples have experienced a complicated thermal history (Fig. 3A). 271 

The mean confined fission track lengths against the AFT ages houfly present a 272 

boomerang shape (Fig. 3B) indicating differential denudation patterns (Gallagher and 273 

Brown, 1997) as also medium to high standard deviation distributions  (Fig. 3C) 274 

suggesting that all samples register a long residence time within the partial annealing 275 

zone.  276 

Broadly speaking, AFT central ages (Table 1; Fig. 4A) measured from the 277 

basement rocks ranges from Middle Triassic (225 ± 15 Ma) to Upper Cretaceous (83 ± 278 

9 Ma) and the mean confined track lengths obtained from 27 samples range from 9.67 ± 279 

0.52 ?m to 13.13 ± 0.16 ?m, with track length distributions predominantly unimodal. 280 

All central AFT ages passed in the ?2 indicating one age population. The Dpar values 281 

(Table 1 and Fig. 3D) indicate a reasonably similar chemical compositions (> 1.75 ?m) 282 



14 

 

and relatively chlorine-rich apatite grains with a higher resistance to annealing 283 

(Donelick et al., 2005). 284 

The oldest ages are dominantly located at the extreme northwest of the area (Fig. 285 

4A) referring to the South Irumide Belt region (mostly NW), also presenting the smaller 286 

lengths measured (ca. 10 ?m; Fig. 3C and 4A). Nevertheless, the largest lengths (> 10 287 

?m) occur around the regional structures, predominantly in the southern region 288 

(Southwest Nampula Complex). This brief variation in the confined track lengths 289 

indicates that samples near the structural trends are fastly denuded.  290 

Thermal history models for samples of the northernmost area were modeled in 291 

three major groups being one to the northeast and the other two to the northwest. The 292 

choice of the samples to be grouped was based mainly on the obtained results in their 293 

individual thermal histories and their geographical position (Fig. 4). The other samples 294 

were also pooled based on the same principles as described below. 295 

Samples from Southern Irumide NE-SW transect (Fig. 1C; Fig. 4 and 4A) near 296 

the East African Rift System, indicate a maximum paleotemperature of 99 °C  at 136 297 

Ma and show a slow cooling pattern until 10 Ma at a temperature of 64 °C (Fig. 4 and 298 

4A). Thereafter, the samples soffers a rapidly cooled to present surface conditions. On 299 

the other hand, the samples of the Southern Irumide north and NW-SE transect (Fig. 300 

1C) record two distinct cooling behavior. Samples MZ-7 and MZ-8 (Fig. 4, 4B and 4C) 301 

show the oldest AFT ages of the whole area (225 ± 15 Ma and 216 ± 15 Ma, 302 

respectively) and indicate a very long time of residence into the partial annealing zone 303 

with moderate reduced mean fission trak length of 9.96 ± 0.24 ?m and 10.86  ± 0.16 304 

?m, respectively. Accelerated cooling until present day surface conditions was only 305 

acheaved in the latter ca. 50 Ma. 306

The Nampula Complex N-S transect (Fig. 1C) registers a similar cooling pattern, 327 

with a relatively slow cooling from maximum paleotemperature of 116 °C at 165 Ma to 56 328 

°C at 17 Ma continuing with a faster cooling pattern until present-day surface conditions 329 

(Fig. 4 and 4D). 330 

Samples from the central region were separated into three groups (Fig. 1 and Fig. 4). 331 

The first comprises the Guro Suite E-W transect (Fig. 4 and 4E) with five samples. Thermal 332 

history of this groups is represented by a stady-state cooling history from 208 Ma to 15 Ma 333 



19 

 

with a maximum paleotemperature of 103 ° C decreasing until 50 ° C in a time spane of ca. 334 

190 Ma, followed by a fast cooling period to the present-day thermal conditions (Fig. 4E). 335 

The thermal behavior observed by the second group (formed by three samples and grouped 336 

as the Guro Suite N-S transect, Fig. 4 and 4F) differs from the former, presenting a rapid 337 

cooling between 190 Ma and 150 Ma, from temperetures of 88 ° C to 76 ° C, followed by a 338 

period of a stationary cooling history unitl 94 Ma. From this moment samples started to 339 

cooling in the same stady-state pattern until 18 Ma when achieved present-day conditings 340 

after a fast cooling event from paleotemperature of 64 ° C. The third one comprises the 341 

samples MZ-18 and MZ-19 located in the Guro Suite of the central portion of the graben of 342 

the structural controlled Zambezi Valley (Fig. 1C) at altitudes of 217 and 314 m, 343 

respectively (Table 1), being lower than the others of this region. As the other samples, the 344 

thermal model indicates a slow cooling of paleotemperatures of the order of 99 ° C to 136 345 

Ma to 60° C at 21 Ma. From 21 Ma these samples soffers a fast cooling until present-day 346 

conditions (Fig. 4G). 347
